Apple seeks to ban Samsung's Galaxy Nexus, but it's really going after Android 4.0

By T.C. Sottek on February 11, 2012 03:31 pm 929 Comments

Apple's intellectual property quest has traditionally gone after manufacturers and their dubiously familiar form factors, but now it looks like the company is aiming straight at Google and Android 4.0: Apple has filed a new motion in the US for a preliminary injunction that would ban the Samsung Galaxy Nexus, Google's flagship Android device.

While Samsung has been the target of Apple's ire with a barrage of other lawsuits, the Galaxy Nexus' hardware isn't really the center of attention here. Since the claim is specifically about key software patents in Android 4.0, other manufacturers putting the latest stock Android OS on their devices could be open to similar lawsuits if the court rules in Apple's favor.

Here are the patents at stake:

  • US Patent No. 5,946,647 - this patent was filed in 1996 (issued 1999) and covers detecting data, such as a phone number, in an email or web page, creating a link to that data, and initiating an action like calling the phone number when the user selects the link. The data could also include addresses, dates, etc.
  • US Patent No. 8,086,604 - this patent claims priority back to 2000 (issued Dec. 2011) and covers searching multiple sources of information (on device and elsewhere) through a single search interface, such as Siri. Apple specifically touts Siri in its injunction request, but also argues that a unified text search is covered by the patent as well.
  • US Patent No. 8,046,721 - this patent claims priority back to 2005 (issued Oct. 2011) and covers Apple's signature slide-to-unlock feature. While Apple already has patent coverage on an image unlock feature, this newest patent is obviously intended to be a bit broader — likely addressing potential workarounds implemented by Google and OEMs over the last couple of years.
  • US Patent No. 8,074,172 - this patent was filed in 2007 (issued Dec. 2011) and covers providing word suggestions while the user types on a touchscreen keyboard, where the suggestions can be accepted or rejected by the user.

Apple already won a ruling over patent #5,946,647 back in December, when the US International Trade Commission banned the importation and sale of HTC Android devices including the Sprint Evo 4G, Verizon Droid Incredible, AT&T Aria, and T-Mobile G2. The other patents in Apple's new claim are relatively new — all having been issued in late 2011 — so we'll have to wait and see what the court decides. We'll be monitoring the progress of Apple's new patent suit closely, and will update you accordingly.

Matt Macari contributed to this report.

  • Source Apple v. Samsung Preliminary Injunction motion

Qfax's reply:

Not the best analogy because of the relative simplicity of a mouse and keyboard compared to a touchscreen-centric operating system as a whole. But if you wanted to force that analogy to fit, it would be a bit more like saying the company who developed scissor action keys saying that no one else can use scissor action keys. You don’t need scissor-action keys to make a keyboard, just as you don’t need slide-to-unlock to make a smartphone. But again, it is not a good analogy because of the comparative complexity of a mobile OS to a mouse and keyboard.

In the mobile OS example there are theoretically infinite ways to accomplish the same basic goal(touchscreen-centric devices) and Apple is asserting ownership on some of those ways. Whether or not they will be able to enforce that claim, has yet to be seen, but given how the system works, they are kind of beholden to try.

Posted on Feb 12, 2012 | 2:59 AM EST reply Recommend Flag actions

Dunn.Hatani's reply:

topsnus probably exaggerated with the “huge” remark but he is not wholly wrong.

There was a pretty big shift in the smartphone market significantly before the iphone. Many smartphones that existed in say 2000-2002 had a UI that was based on a d-pad similar to our current dumb phones. Right around ’02 many phones started to incorporate the touchscreens of the semi-ubiquitous PDA (ie palm pilot, ipaq, etc) into mobile phones. This mostly came in the form of the Treo but there were some windows ce phones out there too.

That market was growing quite rapidly as well. The cellphone existed for a long time before it became ubiquitous and thus required faster development of new technologies. Similarly smartphones were just starting to get on the fast track when apple decided to enter the game. It was a very strategic move on their part and it paid off. Palm and RIM were just starting to make the smartphone popular, but Apple made it ubiquitous.

Those touchscreens while designed with a stylus in mind, did not prohibit the use of a finger on the touchscreen. I personally used my finger on my treo more often than I used the stylus. The virtual keyboards were definitely a pain to use.

My issue with apple’s patents is that they seem to patent the most logical solution to a problem. The inherent problem with touch keyboards is that you have to put your finger on the screen and thus can’t see what exactly you are touching. So how to you make sure you are touching the right button? Well it seems natural to show the result of the finger’s location near the finger but not under it, thus the magnify effect that they use. I really don’t see any other natural solution to this problem. Sure there are other solutions that would work, but they would almost be more hassle than they are worth.

Similarly, in a touch interface it really only seems natural that I would slide my finger up, down, left or right to scroll in that given direction. It seems odd that just because one company does it, that means that another company has to change their interface to use two fingers to scroll, (while an issue at one point this scenario obviously isn’t a problem anymore). It feels to me something like it being natural to use hydraulics to create a more effective braking system on car but prohibiting all but one manufacturer from using hydraulics in brake systems.

Apple did a lot to make the smartphone really useable and mainstream, and they were rewarded handsomely for it. But that shouldn’t mean that they market can’t move forward. And that is exactly what it feels like has happened since software patents were allowed.

Posted on Feb 12, 2012 | 8:24 AM EST reply Recommend Flag actions

Infiniti's reply:

Oh boy! that’s a known (pernicious) myth. It’s hard to kill but I’ll try:

First, the pictures in that article are not from 2007. They possibly are from early 2003-04’s where TouchScreens for phones either weren’t in production or were extremely expensive, so everyone at that time would’ve made a phone with physical buttons only.

Complaining about these things is like complaining about how Train Engine manufacturers started copying each other by moving from Steam engine to Diesel Engines in a few years. It’s just a change is paradigm, nothing else.

Heck, even Apple completely changed their OS design paradigm after seeing what Xerox PARC had created which was followed by Windows, later. You can’t call these things copying.

Next, the (full Touch-enabled) Android SDK was released in around Nov, 2007, which wasn’t too far away from the the first iPhone release. If you’re a software developer, you should know that a smartphone OS cannot be created within months, especially not with the technology that would’ve been present in the 2007 era.

That being said, I give Apple credit to truly changing the smartphone market on a large scale, but at the same time I’d rather stick to the actual facts and reality instead of baseless myths. Android (or Windows Phone, for the matter) might not behave the way it does right now if it weren’t for Apple, but recent times have shown us that the reverse can hold true as well (iOS5 Notifications, etc).

This article does a great job of clearing up some myths about all these Android vs iOS fanboy talk: http://www.osnews.com/story/25264/Did_Android_Really_Look_Like_BlackBerry_Before_the_iPhone_

[Sorry for the TL;DR post]

Look at the Maths:
(For the sake of this example I am assuming the IP various claims by Microsoft and Apple are legitimate and they are entitled to royalties from the sale of Android devices).

1 Assume Microsoft get $5 for each HTC Android handset sold. Assume they get $10 for each HTC Windows Phone sold. An Android sale over a Windows Phone is bad for Microsoft, but not a disaster.

2 Now lets look at Apple. A consumer chooses a HTC phone over an iPhone. Apple would have made ~$100 if they’d chosen an iPhone instead, but now they make $5 instead.

It should be fairly clear now why Microsoft is happy to licence. And Apple isn’t.

MadusMaximus's reply:

Just because something is free (both as in speech and beer) doesn’t mean it gets a pass on infringing patents/copyright and so on. That isn’t how the law works.

Apple sued Samsung on the hardware based on Trade Dress (aka “Passing Off” in the UK for example). There are such things as design patents too, but they relate to the overall look and feel, not just specific parts. It’s those parts as a whole that comprise the protections, and to claim Samsung devices didn’t resemble Apple devices is wishful ignorance at best.

Also, what exactly has ICS innovated on? How is it so far and away better and different from iOS5? They made a new more consistent UI… wow. Is that it? I see very little in the way of innovation, more a case of finally getting the point that things need to be consistent and polished. It’s evolutionary just like iOS updates are.

Apple also DID out-innovate the competition. They also patented the hell out of those innovations, that’s what they’re using as ammunition now to sue those who blatantly ripped them off.

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 6:03 PM EST reply Recommend Flag actions

Cloudgazer's reply:

The Pagerank patent covers more than a specific implementation, it covers almost any algorithm that uses links to determine relevance.

http://www.google.com/patents?vid=6285999

First Claim:

1. A computer implemented method of scoring a plurality of linked documents, comprising:
obtaining a plurality of documents, at least some of the documents being linked documents, at least some of the documents being linking documents, and at least some of the documents being both linked documents and linking documents, each of the linked documents being pointed to by a link in one or more of the linking documents; assigning a score to each of the linked documents based on scores of the one or more linking documents and
processing the linked documents according to their scores.

If you look at that claim, the bolded part is the bit that is novel, it’s a far cry from a specific implementation.

None of that makes it a bad patent, I’m just trying to inject some context and sanity into this.

CoolBone's reply:

It’s a very philosophical question, I agree. I think patents referring to software are complete crap in general.

I think the patent’s need to follow the idea of “Form follows Function.” In the physical world, there are only so many ways to do general concept A by wiring things this way, or adding this chemical to this one, or nailing this bit to that one. That’s why you get awarded a patent for it. But in this competitive software era, I think Laissez Faire needs to play out. If I can prove to you that not only did I exactly copy your functionality, I did it with a different physics system, how is that applicable? Both should be acceptable. Therefore patent invalidated.

iOS doesn’t use or need a complex system to decide what to kill, it kills everything.

Cloudgazer's reply:

It doesn’t cover a system sending the same search to multiple providers and collating the results, but rather one heuristically choosing a provider based on the query.

Cloudgazer's reply:

It helps if you read the claims:

1. A method for locating information in a network using a computer, comprising: receiving by the computer an inputted information descriptor from a user-input device; providing said information descriptor received from the user-input device to a plurality of heuristic modules, wherein: each heuristic module corresponds to a respective area of search and employs a different, predetermined heuristic algorithm corresponding to said respective area to search the area for information that corresponds to the received information descriptor, and the search areas include storage media accessible by the computer; searching by the heuristic modules, based on the received information descriptor, the respective areas of search using the predetermined heuristic algorithms corresponding to each respective area of search; providing at least one candidate item of information located by the heuristic modules as a result of said searching; and displaying by the computer a representation of said candidate item of information on a display device.

This isn’t just searching across all sources, it’s picking sources based on the query.

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 4:03 PM EST reply Recommend (2) Flag actions

Caco's reply:

I fail to understand the meaning. Care to explain in simple English (seriously)? Like what exactly is the difference between windows searching and that patent?

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 4:06 PM EST reply Recommend (1) Flag actions

Cloudgazer's reply:

Something like dogpile, or windows search is searching across all its sources with every query, then sorting results according to some value, then presenting them.

This patent covers a system which decides which sources to search on a per query basis. Is that clear?

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 4:08 PM EST reply Recommend (2) Flag actions

Caco's reply:

TBH, no. I mean I understand what you are saying but don’t understand the principle on which it works. How does it decide which sources to search?

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 4:10 PM EST reply Recommend (1) Flag actions

Cloudgazer's reply:

Using a set of heuristic rules – which is not specified in the patent. So for example if it saw a medical term it could choose to direct the query at a medical database.

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 4:21 PM EST reply Recommend (1) Flag actions

Caco's reply:

Google uses automated programs called spiders or crawlers, just like most search engines. Also like other search engines, Google has a large index of keywords and where those words can be found. Google uses a trademarked algorithm called PageRank, which assigns each Web page a relevancy score.

HowStuffWorks … I know it is rubbish source, but can’t be bothered to read in detail now. How is the Apple system different from that?

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 4:22 PM EST reply Recommend (1) Flag actions

Cloudgazer's reply:

1) Apple isn’t building up a DB, it’s using existing DBs – such as Google, Woflram Alpha etc.
2) Apple isn’t choosing from the DBs afterwards based on relevance of results, it’s choosing between them before hand based on a heuristic decision from the query itself.

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 4:28 PM EST reply Recommend (1) Flag actions

Caco's reply:

1. this simply isn’t an apple invention

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 4:35 PM EST reply Recommend (1) Flag actions

Cloudgazer's reply:

Because the DBs are hardwired in – it has a set of rules for choosing between them. These are implementation details, the precise way the choice is made isn’t relevant to the patent.

Cloudgazer's reply:

I actually think the trade dress is less damaging than the utility patents, but maybe thats because I’m a software guy. While these particularly utility patents are fairly harmless, and will at worst cause a slight degrading of UX – some utility patents have the potential to be devastating, such as the ’283 patent that Apple is still seeking to assert

http://fosspatents.blogspot.com/2012/02/apple-points-itc-to-judge-posners-take.html

In terms of increasing damage to the industry – design and trade dress suits are the least bad, FRAND abuse is the worst, and utility patents span the gap between.

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 5:09 PM EST reply Recommend Flag actions

Cloudgazer's reply:

Ok – here is claim 1 of the slide to unlock patent:

1. A method of unlocking a hand-held electronic device, the device including a touch-sensitive display, the method comprising: detecting a contact with the touch-sensitive display at a first predefined location corresponding to an unlock image; continuously moving the unlock image on the touch-sensitive display in accordance with movement of the contact while continuous contact with the touch screen is maintained, wherein the unlock image is a graphical, interactive user-interface object with which a user interacts in order to unlock the device; and unlocking the hand-held electronic device if the moving the unlock image on the touch-sensitive display results in movement of the unlock image from the first predefined location to a predefined unlock region on the touch-sensitive display.

The NeoNode N1M, while clearly ahead of its time doesn’t implement the patent and thus does not constitute invalidating prior art. There’s no graphical element that is being moved to effect the gestural unlock.

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 7:19 PM EST reply Recommend (1) Flag actions

Cameronbic's reply:
5. The method of claim 4, wherein the visual cues comprise text.

6. The method of claim 4, wherein said visual cues comprise an arrow indicating a general direction of movement.

And does this not require that the violating method include text or an arrow?

Posted on Feb 11, 2012 | 9:03 PM EST reply Recommend Flag actions

Cloudgazer's reply:

Each claim is essentially independent, i.e. if you violate claim 1 you violate the patent. The more specific claims are included in case somebody invalidates the broader ones with prior art.

So Claim 6 is the only one that requires an arrow, you can violate claim 1 without one.

To violate a patent you must practice one of the claims in it’s entirety.

aThingOrTwo's reply:

I appreciate the clarification – thank you and I am 100% in agreement with you that petty patents are petty.

I do disagree that there is “right” way to defend IP. I think it depends on the circumstances. Requiring a company A to always cross license when company B infringes seems unfair on company A in my eyes.

For the case of Patent No. 5,946,647, I would say that looking at an email and interpreting meaningful information such as the date of an appointment, telephone number, address, flight number is a bit different to mapping all files ending in .xls, to Excel. In other words – the clever bit is not in what happens when the user clicks the link, but rather how the link is generated in the first place.

I don’t want to get into whether it is patent worthy because I don’t know enough to make a good judgement.

TravisT42's reply:

It boils down to this:

Google: Tosses your search query at all of the indexed links (i.e. everything), returns all the hits after using heuristics to determine the most relevant results and then ranking them accordingly.

Apple: Uses heuristics to determine which DB(s) of links (i.e. subset(s) of everything) is most relevant to your query, then searches only those links and returns the results.

JWDAV's reply:

Apple may or may not infringe that patent. Even if it looks and works the same, if the methods Apple & Google use ti implement the feature are different, neither one infringes the other.

No car manufacturer could patent headlights as an idea, but many manufacturers could patent different headlight designs as implementations of the idea. Every manufacturer would have “stolen” the idea for headlights, but copying an idea with an original method of implementing the idea is not in violation of anything.

Cloudgazer's reply:

Simple – read the claims:

1. A method, comprising: at a portable electronic device with a touch screen display: in a first area of the touch screen display, displaying a current character string being input by a user with the keyboard; in a second area of the touch screen display that is between the first area and the keyboard, displaying the current character string or a portion thereof and a suggested replacement character string for the current character string on opposite sides of the second area; replacing the current character string in the first area with the suggested replacement character string if the user activates a space bar key on the keyboard; replacing the current character string in the first area with the suggested replacement character string if the user performs a first gesture on the suggested replacement character string displayed in the second area; and keeping the current character string in the first area and adding a space if the user performs a second gesture in the second area on the current character string or the portion thereof displayed in the second area.

There’s a lot of text in that first claim eh? It’s not just a claim on auto-suggestion – it’s a claim on a specific UI approach to auto-correction. It’s perfectly possible to auto-correct without infringing it. For example if you put the suggestion above the typing rather than below you would not infringe.

sle0609's reply:

you are allowed patent a new a unique implementation of a feature that doesn’t infringe prior art.

apple isn’t patenting the features themselves, just their way of executing those features. for example you are allowed to create and sell a car you made in your own garage despite the fact that cars were invented by someone else hundreds of years ago. you are also allowed to patent what makes you car unique so that others can’t freely copy your work (not without your permission or payment at least).

and if someone comes along and copies your work you are allowed to sue them. just as they are allowed to change their designs to come up with their own unique way of doing things that avoid infringing your patents.

kaicherry's reply:

1. mailto: isn’t nearly the same as Apple “data detector” technology, which does very specific things and has been doing it at the API level, as describe in what they patented for years and YEARS before they move the technology (which is in their base API set) from the desktop to the mobile space

3. Again, Apple isn’t trying to claim general concepts. Again, disingenuous.

4. The earlier forms of text prediction do not work the same way. AGAIN Apple doesn’t claim to have ownership over the mere concept..

Pple is NOT behaving as if they “invented mobile phones”…in fact they are behaving as if they introduced several innovative concepts that re-defined some fairly long-standing user interactions and methodologies. The problem here is that you, and people like you, seem to willfully, out of ignorance or malice, continually substitute the word forms of “invent” with the word forms of “innovate” and they do not mean the same thing. They are NOT synonyms…this is why they have fundamentally different definitions…perhaps you should look them up.

kaicherry says:

You know…I think the thing that really, truly bothers me, deep down, about this debate is the complete and utter lack of honesty in it. This is the 21st century and we are all supposedly technically saavy and smart people here…why can we cut the dissonance and if we are going to argue, argue from reality?

As much as people seem to have some irrational vitriolic hate for Apple, which is fine, everyone is entitled to their opinions, what I just do NOT understand is why people continue with this notion that Apple didn’t invent some of this stuff, that “everyone” was doing it…that Apple has somehow co-opted this stuff as their own and Android has been like it is for the most part “all along” when it simply isn’t true.

Before iOS, pretty much all phones were variations on some specific themes; how you did icons, how you accessed menus, form factors, etc. We were ALL THERE. We ALL know this. But you know what? Let’s look at Andriod as it existed, pre-iOS lifted fundamental changes…from Google themselves: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1FJHYqE0RDg&feature=player_embedded

There are no full screen, scrolling menus here: because NO ONE made an OS that did this, menus came up from the bottom and had key equivalent. The hardware has sharp corners…because that is pretty much what you did…etc and etc and so on.

Look at it. This was what they had been working on, in the labs. This was their big unveil. This was their product. They say so. They showed it.

Then they went back to the lab and lifted what they could from iOS before their initial launch, making fundamental changes to what they did to match Apple’s stuff. These are the facts. It isn’t fanyboism, it isn’t an opinion…it is, as it is said, “what it is.”

So, if people are going to debate who did who wrong and who is “patenting rectangles” can we at LEAST be honest and say look…this is what it was, and this is what happened…and “debate” from there?

kaicherry's reply:

The answer to your screed is simple: Do what Apple did and come up with a novel way to do these things that no one else did before, then patent the novel way. This is what innovation actually means…a distinct class of work from invention.

Invention: “make a way to search for something.”
Innovation: “make a different way to search for something that someone hasn’t come up with before.”

You can still “search”. You can still search the “old way”. You can even make an even newer way to search that the innovator didn’t think of..and then they can’t use yours either.

In none of these above cases did anyone invent the concept of searching.

Apply this to any and all things that are being debated here and don’t cross-pollute the concepts and it all becomes clear; some people are using a fallacy basis for their arguments “apple or google or moto or spongbob or whomever is trying to ‘patent’ some ‘simple basic thing’ and trying to prevent anyone else from doing this same ‘simple basic thing’!!! MY HEAD IS GONNA ‘SPLODE IF THIS DOESN’T STOP!”

The problem is, this extreme false case isn’t what is happening in reality…just in some of the more misguided comments :)

Richard Labas says:

I think the problem Apple have is with the patent system. You can’t actually patent “the whole thing”, just individual small patents. There is no problem, if Linux use data detectors, or Nokia use slide to unlock feature. There is a problem, if Apple invents mouse and GUI (ok, they bought it from Xerox Parc, but they bought it, not stole) and someone copy everything they can. They don’t care about “trash bin design” patent, or “window design” patent, they do care about the whole package (look and feel), which isn’t patentable. So, instead, they fire with everything they have.

Thats exactly what we can see here, in Apple vs Samsung (and Android in general) case. Apple didn’t invent touchscreen or phone or apps. They did invent the “modern smartphone” package, which isn’t patentable. It includes minimal number of buttons, touchscreen taking all of the space, grid of apps, appstore, full web browser etc. They don’t care about things like MeeGo or Windows Phone, which may be covered by some patents, but they are generally different. They do care, if someone does almost exactly the same, so they fire with every small patent they have. Of course, they do get backfire, so they do have whole patent war.

I don’t want to judge either side, I just want to show an overlooked side of the war. That patents are just “soldiers”, it isn’t about “slide to unlock” feature. It is about copying the whole package. Its up to you to decide, if Samsung+Android are just a cheap iPhone, or something truly innovative. Apple thinks it is just a cheap iPhone, Google and Android vendors think they are not, everybody is entitled to their own opinion. Let the court decide.
